questions.text: Compared with cow's milk, mother's milk has more
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Mother's milk, or human milk, contains a higher concentration of lactose compared to cow's milk.

  • Lactose is the primary carbohydrate found in milk, and it provides a source of energy for infants.
  • Human milk is specially formulated to meet the nutritional needs of human infants, and lactose is a key component that supports their growth and development.

Vitamin D (Option B): Cow's milk is often fortified with vitamin D, but the natural vitamin D content in human milk is generally lower. However, the vitamin D content of a mother's milk can vary depending on factors such as maternal diet, sun exposure, and supplementation. In some cases, breastfed infants may require additional vitamin D supplementation to meet their needs, especially if they have limited exposure to sunlight.

Explanation:

Fish oil is one of the richest sources of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), which are omega-3 fatty acids.

  • EPA and DHA are commonly found in fatty fish such as salmon, mackerel, sardines, and trout.
  • These omega-3 fatty acids are known for their numerous health benefits, including reducing inflammation, supporting heart health, and promoting brain function.

Groundnut oil (Peanut oil) (Option A): Groundnut oil, also known as peanut oil, is primarily composed of monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats, but it is not particularly rich in eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA). Instead, groundnut oil is more abundant in another type of omega-3 fatty acid called alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), which is less potent than EPA in providing health benefits.

Safflower oil (Option C): Safflower oil is primarily composed of monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats, particularly linoleic acid, which is an omega-6 fatty acid. While safflower oil is a healthy cooking oil choice, it does not contain significant amounts of EPA.

Sunflower oil (Option D): Sunflower oil is also primarily composed of monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats, with linoleic acid being the predominant omega-6 fatty acid. Similar to safflower oil, sunflower oil does not contain notable amounts of EPA.

In summary, option B (Fish oil) is the correct answer because fish oil is rich in eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), making it a valuable source of omega-3 fatty acids. Options A, C, and D primarily contain other types of fatty acids and are not particularly rich sources of EPA. Therefore, option B is the most appropriate choice.

questions.text: In measles, which vitamin deficiency occurs
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Measles infection can lead to a temporary vitamin A deficiency.

  • Measles affects the respiratory system and can cause symptoms such as fever, cough, and runny nose.
  • It also affects the eyes and mucous membranes, leading to symptoms like conjunctivitis (pink eye).
  • Vitamin A deficiency can worsen the severity and duration of measles and increase the risk of complications, including blindness and death.

While measles may indirectly affect overall nutrition and lead to deficiencies in other vitamins, such as B and C (Options B&C), there is no direct association between measles and these specific deficiencies. Vitamin D (Option D) is also not directly related to measles infection.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of night blindness in children between 6 months to 6 years is more than:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of night blindness in children between 6 months to 6 years is more than 1%.

  • Night blindness is a clinical sign of vitamin A deficiency. It occurs due to the impaired ability of the eyes to adapt to low-light conditions, leading to difficulty seeing in dim light or darkness.
  • It is one of the earliest manifestations of vitamin A deficiency and is commonly used as an indicator to assess the prevalence of vitamin A deficiency in a population.
  • Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of night blindness in children between 6 months to 6 years is more than 1%.
  • This threshold is used by public health authorities and organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO) to identify populations at risk of vitamin A deficiency and to implement interventions such as supplementation or fortification of food.

choices.text: 1 lakh IU on day 0,1, and 14
2 lakh IU on day 0, 1, and 14

questions.text: A 10-month-old child weighing 8 kg has the following lesion in both eyes. Which of the following is the most appropriate schedule to prescribe vitamin A?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Recommended WHO treatment for children with signs of vitamin A deficiency (such as Bitot spots):

  • 1 lakh IU (100,000 IU) of vitamin A on day 0
  • Repeat 1 lakh IU on day 1
  • Final dose of 1 lakh IU on day 14

This 3-dose regimen is:

  • Intended for children aged 6-11 months
  • For children aged 12 months and above, the dose is typically 200,000 IU at the same intervals

Goal of supplementation:

  • Replenish liver stores of vitamin A
  • Reverse ocular signs
  • Prevent serious complications (e.g., corneal ulceration, blindness)

questions.text: Decreased level of serum Vitamin B6 is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Decreased level of serum Vitamin B6 is seen in isoniazid therapy.

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6)

  • Forms: Exists in three forms - pyridoxine, pyridoxal, and pyridoxamine.
  • Functions:
    • Essential for the metabolism of amino acids, fats, and carbohydrates.
    • Plays a role in neurotransmitter synthesis and red blood cell formation.
  • Sources:
    • Found in a wide variety of foods, including:
      • Milk, liver, meat, fish, egg yolk
      • Whole grain cereals
      • Legumes and vegetables
  • Deficiency Effects:
    • Most notably associated with peripheral neuritis (nerve inflammation causing numbness or tingling).
    • Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can impair the body's ability to utilize pyridoxine effectively.
    • Isoniazid (INH), a drug used to treat tuberculosis, can block pyridoxine action - hence patients on INH are often given 10 mg/day of pyridoxine preventively.
  • Daily Requirements:
    • Adults: ~2 mg/day (needs increase with higher protein intake)
    • Pregnancy and lactation: ~2.5 mg/day
  • Deficiency Status:
    • Rare, as balanced diets typically provide adequate amounts.

Chronic Renal Failure (Option A): While chronic renal failure (CRF) can lead to various metabolic disturbances and deficiencies in certain vitamins and minerals, such as vitamin D and calcium, it is not typically associated with decreased levels of serum vitamin B6. However, individuals with CRF may have an increased risk of vitamin B6 deficiency due to dietary restrictions, impaired absorption, or other factors.

Chronic Heart Failure (Option B): Chronic heart failure (CHF) is a condition characterized by the heart's inability to pump blood effectively, leading to various systemic effects. While CHF can impact the body's overall metabolism and nutrient status, decreased levels of serum vitamin B6 are not commonly associated with this condition.

Alcohol (Option D): Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to various nutritional deficiencies, including deficiencies in B vitamins such as thiamine (B1), riboflavin (B2), niacin (B3), and folate (B9). While alcohol can also impact the metabolism and utilization of vitamin B6, decreased levels of serum vitamin B6 are not solely attributed to alcohol consumption and may be influenced by other factors.

questions.text: Which of the following improve the absorption of oral iron pills?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, is well known for its ability to enhance the absorption of non-heme iron (the type of iron found in plant-based foods and iron supplements).

Iron Absorption and Metabolism

  • Site of Absorption:
    • Iron is mainly absorbed in the duodenum and upper small intestine.
    • It is best absorbed in its ferrous (Fe2+) form.
  • Regulation:
    • Absorption is regulated by the body's iron needs - more is absorbed when body stores are low.
  • Factors Influencing Absorption:
    • Enhancers:
      • Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) and foods rich in it improve absorption.
    • Inhibitors:
      • Phosphates, phytates, and tannins reduce absorption. (Options A, C, & D)
    • Medical Conditions:
      • Diseases affecting the duodenum and jejunum (e.g., celiac disease, tropical sprue) can impair iron uptake.
  • Increased Requirements:
    • Iron absorption increases during periods of greater physiological need, such as pregnancy.
  • Bioavailability:
    • Iron absorption from typical Indian diets is less than 5%, mainly due to low bioavailability from plant-based sources and inhibitors.
  • Transport & Storage:
    • Absorbed iron is carried in the blood as plasma ferritin.
    • Stored primarily in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and kidneys.
  • Conservation Mechanism:
    • The body recycles iron efficiently.
    • When red blood cells break down, their iron content is reused to form new red cells.

questions.text: A farmer whose predominant diet is maize has presented with a hyperpigmented skin lesion around the neck. Which of the following is not a significant history/ finding in this patient pointing to the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hyperpigmented skin lesions around the neck, often referred to as "necklace sign" or "casal necklace," are characteristic dermatological manifestations of pellagra.

  • While family history is important in assessing the risk of certain conditions, it is less relevant in the context of pellagra, which is primarily caused by dietary deficiencies rather than genetic factors.
  • Maize is a staple food in many regions, particularly in areas where pellagra is prevalent, and it is deficient in niacin unless treated with alkali, such as lime.

Niacin Deficiency and Pellagra

  • Pellagra is the clinical disease that results from a deficiency of niacin (Vitamin B3).
  • It is classically marked by the "3 D's":
    • Diarrhoea (Option A)
    • Dermatitis
    • Dementia (Option B)
  • Other associated symptoms include:
    • Glossitis (inflammation of the tongue) (Option D)
    • Stomatitis (inflammation of the mouth)
  • Dermatitis:
    • Appears bilaterally symmetrical
    • Limited to sun-exposed areas like the:
      • Backs of hands
      • Lower legs
      • Face
      • Neck
  • Mental symptoms may include:
    • Depression
    • Irritability
    • Delirium
  • Epidemiology:
    • Pellagra was once widespread among malnourished populations dependent primarily on maize-based diets.
    • Though it has declined globally, it still exists in certain areas of Western Asia and Southern Africa.
  • Cause in Maize and Jowar Eaters:
    • The disease is linked to an amino acid imbalance, particularly due to excess leucine.
    • High leucine intake inhibits the conversion of tryptophan to niacin, worsening the deficiency.
  • Cases in India:
    • Pellagra has been documented in Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, where some populations rely heavily on jowar (sorghum) and have low intake of animal foods like milk.

questions.text: A girl presented with dryness of eyes, and her elbows are showing lesions as shown in the image. What is this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phrynoderma is a dermatological condition characterized by follicular hyperkeratotic papules or plaques, often present on the extensor surfaces of the limbs, such as the elbows and knees.

  • These lesions typically occur due to a deficiency of vitamin A or essential fatty acids, or a combination of both.
  • Dryness of the eyes (xerophthalmia) is a characteristic symptom of vitamin A deficiency, which can occur concomitantly with phrynoderma.

Ocular symptoms of Vitamin A deficiency:

  • Nightblindness
  • Conjunctival xerosis
  • Bitot's spots
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Keratomalacia

Extra-Ocular Manifestations of Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Non-ocular symptoms include:
    • Follicular hyperkeratosis (rough, bumpy skin due to abnormal keratinization)
    • Anorexia (loss of appetite)
    • Growth retardation in children
  • These signs are:
    • Non-specific (can be caused by other conditions)
    • Difficult to measure accurately
  • Recent findings suggest:
    • Even mild vitamin A deficiency can lead to increased risk of infections, especially:
      • Respiratory infections
      • Gastrointestinal infections

Eczema (Option B): Eczema refers to a group of inflammatory skin conditions characterized by redness, itching, and sometimes the formation of vesicles or papules. While eczema can manifest with dry, scaly skin lesions, it typically presents with a different distribution pattern and morphology compared to phrynoderma.

Ichthyosis (Option C): Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders characterized by dry, scaly skin with a "fish scale" appearance. While ichthyosis may present with similar dryness of the skin, the specific pattern and morphology of lesions in phrynoderma are different from those seen in ichthyosis.

Keratosis pilaris rubra (Option D): Keratosis pilaris rubra is a common skin condition characterized by small, rough bumps on the skin, typically on the upper arms, thighs, cheeks, or buttocks. While keratosis pilaris rubra may also present with dry, rough skin, it typically lacks the follicular hyperkeratotic papules or plaques seen in phrynoderma.

questions.text: Which nutrient is deficient in breast milk?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Breast milk is generally well-balanced and provides essential nutrients for infant growth and development. However, one notable nutrient that is deficient in breast milk is vitamin K. Vitamin K plays a crucial role in blood clotting, and newborns are born with low levels of vitamin K.

Forms and Sources

  • Exists mainly in two forms:
    • Vitamin K1 (phylloquinone) - Found in fresh, dark green vegetables and some fruits.
    • Vitamin K2 (menaquinone) - Produced by gut bacteria in the human intestine.
  • Cow's milk contains more vitamin K (~60 mcg/L) than human milk (~15 mcg/L).

Synthesis and Absorption

  • Intestinal bacteria generally provide sufficient vitamin K for healthy individuals.
  • Long-term antibiotic use (more than a week) can disrupt gut flora, reducing vitamin K production and potentially leading to deficiency.
  • Vitamin K is stored in the liver.

Newborn Considerations

  • Newborns are prone to vitamin K deficiency due to:
    • Low vitamin K stores at birth
    • Underdeveloped gut flora
  • Prophylaxis recommendation: A single intramuscular injection soon after birth of:
    • 1-0.2 mg of menadione sodium bisulphite or
    • 5 mg of vitamin K

Vitamin A (Option A): Breast milk is a good source of vitamin A, which is essential for vision, immune function, and growth. Adequate levels of vitamin A are typically present in breast milk, so it is not deficient in breast milk.

Vitamin B (Option C): Vitamin B is a group of water-soluble vitamins that play various roles in metabolism, energy production, and nervous system function. Breast milk contains various B vitamins, including thiamine (B1), riboflavin (B2), niacin (B3), pantothenic acid (B5), pyridoxine (B6), biotin (B7), and cobalamin (B12). While the levels of specific B vitamins in breast milk may vary, breast milk is generally not deficient in vitamin B as a group.

Pantothenic acid (Option D): Pantothenic acid, also known as vitamin B5, is important for energy metabolism and synthesizing hormones and cholesterol. Breast milk contains pantothenic acid, although the exact levels may vary. Breast milk is not typically deficient in pantothenic acid.

choices.text: 400 Kcal in the second trimester
400 kcal in the third trimester
200 Kcal in the second trimester

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the additional nutritional calories in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During pregnancy, additional nutritional caloric intake is necessary to support the growth and development of the foetus and to meet the increased energy demands of the mother. The recommended additional caloric intake is generally around 300-350 kcal per day throughout the pregnancy.

Energy Requirements for Pregnant and Lactating Women

  • Pregnancy increases a woman's energy needs to support fetal growth and maternal tissue development.
    • +350 kcal/day is recommended throughout pregnancy in addition to her regular energy requirement.
  • Lactation demands even more energy to support breast milk production:
    • +600 kcal/day during the first 6 months of breastfeeding.
    • +520 kcal/day during the next 6 months of continued breastfeeding.
  • These additional calories ensure:
    • Adequate nutrient supply for the baby
    • Maintenance of maternal health
    • Proper milk secretion and energy balance

questions.text: Of the total dietary energy per day, the ratio of energy coming from carbohydrates/ fats/ proteins should ideally be
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Recommended Energy Distribution in a Balanced Diet:

  • Carbohydrates: ~65% of total energy intake
    • Serve as the primary energy source for the body.
    • Emphasis should be on complex carbohydrates like:
      • Whole grains
      • Fruits
      • Vegetables
    • These sources also provide essential nutrients and dietary fibre, supporting stable blood sugar levels.
  • Fats: ~20% of total energy intake
    • Provide energy, support cell growth, and help protect organs.
    • Limit intake of saturated and trans fats to reduce the risk of heart disease.
    • Focus on healthy fats (e.g., from nuts, seeds, fish, and vegetable oils).
  • Proteins: ~15% of total energy intake
    • Crucial for tissue repair, growth, and immune function.
    • Recommended protein sources:
      • Lean meats, poultry, and fish
      • Legumes (e.g., lentils, chickpeas)
      • Nuts and seeds
  • This macronutrient distribution aligns with global health guidelines from WHO and IOM, promoting overall well-being and nutritional adequacy.

questions.text: First clinical sign of vitamin A deficiency is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Conjunctival xerosis, characterized by dryness and roughening of the conjunctiva, is often the first clinical sign of vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: The highest thiamine content is found in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gingelly seeds, or sesame seeds, are rich in thiamine, making them an excellent dietary source of this vitamin.

  • Thiamine plays a crucial role in energy metabolism and nerve function.
  • Gingelly seeds can be consumed whole, ground into paste (tahini), or used as oil, providing versatility in incorporating them into various dishes.

questions.text: Which of the following provides the least amount of energy in the body?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alcohol provides approximately 7 calories per gram when metabolized in the body.

Alcoholic Beverages:

  • Common types: Beer, whisky, rum, gin, brandy, arrack
  • Alcohol content:
    • Beer: 5-6%
    • Spirits (e.g., whisky, rum, gin): 40-45%
  • Caloric value of alcohol:
    • 7 kcal per gram
